shiva_story.definition: Lord Shiva, also known as Mahadeva, is one of the principal deities in Sanatana Dharma, representing destruction, transformation, and ultimate reality.

origin.roots: Vedic tradition evolving into Puranic texts

appearance: Third eye on forehead (symbol of wisdom and destruction of ignorance)
Crescent moon on head (control over time)
Ganga flowing from hair (source of life and purification)
Blue throat (Neelkanth) from consuming poison during Samudra Manthan
Trident (Trishula) representing creation, preservation, and destruction
Damru (drum) symbolizing cosmic sound and rhythm
attributes.vehicle: Nandi (bull) – symbol of strength and devotion

major_legends.name: Creation of the Universe
major_legends.summary: Shiva performs the cosmic dance (Tandava) to create, sustain, and dissolve the universe.

major_legends.name: Samudra Manthan
major_legends.summary: During the churning of the ocean, Shiva consumes the deadly poison (Halahala) to save the world, earning the name Neelkanth.

major_legends.name: Marriage to Parvati
major_legends.summary: Shiva marries Goddess Parvati, symbolizing union of consciousness and energy (Shakti).

major_legends.name: Destruction of Kama
major_legends.summary: Shiva burns Kama (god of desire) with his third eye, teaching control over desires.

major_legends.name: Daksha Yagna
major_legends.summary: Shiva destroys Daksha's sacrifice after Sati's self-immolation, emphasizing respect for divine principles.

symbolism: Third eye – Higher perception beyond physical reality.
Crescent moon – Time and cycles under control.
Ganga – Flow of wisdom and purification.
Trishula – Balance of creation, preservation, destruction.
forms_of_shiva: Ardhanarishvara – Half Shiva, half Parvati (unity of masculine and feminine).
Lingam – Abstract representation of infinite consciousness.

philosophical_significance.advaita: Shiva represents pure consciousness beyond duality.
philosophical_significance.yoga: Lord of meditation and inner stillness.

festivals.name: Maha Shivaratri
festivals.significance: Night of Shiva, symbolizing spiritual awakening.

modern_relevance.spirituality: Symbol of inner strength and transformation.
modern_relevance.culture: Inspires art, music, and dance globally.
